content: The "Targeted Tax Lien Act of 2010" modifies lien notice filing procedures. The "Targeted Tax Lien Act of 2010" amends Section 6323 of the Internal Revenue Code to require specific procedures before filing a notice of lien, ensuring that the benefit to the Federal Government outweighs the filing. The "Targeted Tax Lien Act of 2010" amends Section 6323 of the Internal Revenue Code to require specific procedures before filing a notice of lien, ensuring that the benefit to the Federal Government outweighs the harm to the taxpayer and does not jeopardize their ability to comply with tax laws or secure funding for business operations. Factors considered include the amount due. The IRS must consider the amount due, lien filing fee, taxpayer's equity, tax compliance history, extenuating circumstances, and impact on financing and future income before filing a notice of lien. Taxpayer must be notified before the lien is filed. The IRS must notify the taxpayer before filing a notice of lien and provide an opportunity to appeal the determination to the Internal Revenue Service Office of Appeals. A notice of lien may not be filed without supervisory approval in certain cases. The amendment requires individual review and approval for cases involving economic hardship, lack of assets, or no personal contact with the taxpayer. Effective upon enactment of the Act. Modification of requirements regarding tax lien information in consumer credit reports. Modification of requirements regarding tax lien information in consumer credit reports. Paragraph (3) of section 605(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to specify conditions for tax liens to be included in consumer reports, including timeframes for lien release and refiling. The amendment specifies conditions for tax liens to be included in consumer reports, including timeframes for lien release and refiling, with an effective date upon enactment of the Act.
